abstracts.cdata!:
The Lakhdar Watershed Management Pilot
            Project tests--on a pilot basis--participatory approaches to
            improve land use and natural resource management in
            mountainous areas. The project is the first attempt to test
            the conclusions of the National Watershed Management Study
            carried out to take stock of past experiences in watershed
            management and apply the lessons learned. There are three
            components. The first consists of soil and water
            conservation and erosion control measures carried out with
            the active participation of the communities concerned on
            public, collective, and private lands. These measures
            include 1) protecting gullies and ravines on all lands,
            improving range lands in degraded sylvopastoral lands, and
            revegetating badlands progressively; 2) funding
            participative forest management with pilot operations to
            regularize illicit settlements, reforesting, and improving
            socio-economic infrastructure; 3) rehabilitating small-scale
            irrigation systems; and 4) intensifying irrigated and
            rain-fed crop production, planting fruit trees, and
            sponsoring field demonstrations and farmers' days. The
            second component, socio-economic infrastructure, finances
            access roads, water supply schemes, and technical studies.
            The third component finances four-wheel drive vehicles,
            office furniture and equipment including computer equipment,
            and a training program for project staff, elected
            representatives, and local administration officials.
